content: The U.S. Army dispatched soldiers to patrol the streets of Samson, Alabama, a small southern town where a rampaging gunman killed 10 people on Tuesday. This obvious violation of the Posse Comitatus Act prohibiting the federal uniformed services from exercising state and local law enforcement was completely ignored by the corporate media with the exception of Reuters and the London Telegraph featured stories U.S. Army Puts Soldiers on the Street in Alabama in Response to Shootings On September 30, 2008, the Army Times reported the 3rd Infantry Divisions 1st Brigade Combat Team, a component of Northern Command, would be on-call in response to natural or manmade emergencies and disasters, including terrorist attacks. The Army Times article reported the military would be used for crowd and traffic control and be issued nonlethal weapons designed to subdue unruly or dangerous individuals without killing them. According to the article, expectations are that another, as yet unnamed, active-duty brigade will take over and that the mission will be a permanent one.. "Diplomacy is utterly useless when there is no force behind it; the diplomat is the servant, not the master of the soldier." THEODORE ROOSEVELT

content: quote: I never said conspiracy, but it is curious how this was reported in GB well before it was here. Well now ... maybe, just maybe, that's because in this neck of the woods, it was perceived as a "good news" story and we all know our media doesn't like to report anything positive. The folks down here are grateful for the MPs responding (under control of the Provost Marshal no less) to the little 5-man Sampson LE call for help from adjacent communities. You think maybe the PM went to ensure that the MPs stayed within the constraints of Posse Comitatus? The MPs helped with traffic control and (maybe) with securing the crime scenes from contamination ... BFD. Unlike some places where the military and civilian communities are at loggerheads, around here the military and community actually cooperate pretty well. When a tornado hit Enterprise, AL two years ago, didn't see any stupid retards complaining about the Flatiron medevac flights that Ft Rucker flew ... or the soldiers that helped clear the rubble of the two schools flattened by the tornado that killed eight students ... or the other Flatiron medevacs routinely flown by Rucker for victims of car accidents and other incidents. There's always some irrational twit that will take a "good deed" and try and paint it as evil. Perhaps that's why there are so few good deeds these days. This message has been edited.
